Michigan Initial Health & Safety Training Module B
Section 1: Child Development

Growth Patterns

Let’s discuss growth patterns of a child. Infants usually lose a small amount of weight from birth to 2 weeks old.

There are two physical growth spurts in a child’s life. The first is from 2 weeks until 1 year old. The second is during puberty.

  1. Birth - 2 Weeks: Weight Loss

    Soon after birth, infants lose 5 to 10 % of their birth weight.

  2. 2 Weeks - 1 Year: Rapid Growth & Weight Gain

    By 2 weeks old the infant begins to gain weight and continues to grow quickly. The general rule of thumb is that we like to see a child double their birth weight by 6 months old and triple it by 12 months old.

  3. 1-5 Years: 5 lbs. per Year

    From ages 1 year to 5 years children average a 5-pound weight gain each year.

  4. 5-10 Years: Steady Pace

    Children continue to grow steadily until around 10 years old.

  5. Puberty: Rapid Growth Spurt

    A child’s final growth spurt begins at puberty. This can be anytime between 9 and 15 years old.

A child’s nutritional needs correspond with changes in their growth rate. During infancy and adolescence children need more calories in relationship to their size.
